definitions: move away backward from a previous position or place gradually
become weaker or less noticeable over time as influence diminishes
examples: The floodwater began to recede after several days
His hairline started to recede in his thirties
Her anger began to recede as she calmed down
The pain will recede once the medication takes effect

definitions: cause metal to lose its shine and become dull or discolored
damage or spoil the good opinion people have about something or someone
examples: Silver jewelry will tarnish if not properly stored
The humid air caused the brass fixtures to tarnish
The scandal threatened to tarnish his political career
One bad review won't tarnish the restaurant's excellent reputation

definitions: increase the volume or strength of sound using electronic equipment
make something larger stronger or more important by adding to it
examples: The speakers amplify the singer's voice throughout the stadium
We need to amplify the signal for better reception
Social media can amplify both positive and negative messages
The report aims to amplify the voices of marginalized communities

definitions: gradually become smaller in size amount or strength over time
examples: Our food supplies began to dwindle during the storm
The crowd dwindled as the evening grew colder

definitions: get on a ship aircraft or other vehicle to start a journey
begin a new project activity or period in life with enthusiasm
examples: Passengers began to embark on the cruise ship
We will embark from the harbor at dawn tomorrow
She decided to embark on a new career in medicine
The company will embark on an ambitious expansion plan

definitions: provide care food and protection to help someone or something grow and develop
examples: Parents nurture their children with love and guidance
The gardener carefully nurtured the seedlings until spring

definitions: cover someone or something completely preventing air from reaching them
give someone too much love or attention making them feel trapped
examples: He used a blanket to smother the small kitchen fire
The thick smoke threatened to smother everyone in the room
Some parents smother their children with excessive protection
She felt her boyfriend was trying to smother her

definitions: support defend or maintain a law principle or decision as valid or correct
examples: The court decided to uphold the original verdict
Teachers must uphold high standards in their classrooms

definitions: defeat an enemy or opponent completely in battle competition or conflict
examples: The hero set out to vanquish the dragon
Our team managed to vanquish the defending champions

definitions: move in an unsteady way from side to side while standing
be unable to make a decision or lose confidence in something
examples: The flame began to waver in the strong wind
She wavered on her feet after standing too long
He began to waver in his support for the project
Don't waver from your original plan despite the criticism

definitions: make a gesture with hand or head to encourage someone to come closer
examples: The teacher beckoned the shy student to the front
She beckoned me over with a wave of her hand

definitions: climb or move using both hands and feet in an awkward way
examples: The children clambered over the rocks at the beach
We had to clamber up the steep muddy hillside

definitions: cause a group to separate and go in different directions across an area
examples: Police arrived to disperse the crowd after the concert
The seeds disperse naturally when the pod opens

definitions: completely surround cover or swallow something overwhelming it from all sides
examples: The flames quickly engulfed the abandoned wooden building
A feeling of sadness engulfed her after the news

definitions: grow or develop successfully in a healthy vigorous way especially in good conditions
wave something around in a dramatic way to attract attention
examples: The plants flourish in this warm humid climate
Small businesses flourish when the community supports them
The magician flourished his cape before the final trick
She flourished the winning lottery ticket above her head

definitions: complain about something in a quiet but bad-tempered way
examples: The employees grumbled about working on the weekend
He tends to grumble when dinner is late

definitions: create difficulties that result in delay or prevent progress
examples: The heavy rain will hinder our construction progress
Don't let fear hinder you from pursuing your dreams

definitions: light up a place or object with bright light making it visible
help to explain something or make it easier to understand
examples: Streetlights illuminate the path through the park at night
Candles illuminated the dining room during the power outage
The professor's examples helped illuminate the complex theory
This new evidence illuminates the mystery of what happened

definitions: push bump or knock against someone roughly typically in a crowd
examples: People jostled each other trying to board the train
The crowd jostled forward when the gates finally opened

definitions: start a fire by lighting wood paper or other material
arouse or inspire an emotion interest or feeling in someone
examples: She used dry leaves to kindle the campfire
It took several matches to kindle the damp wood
The teacher hoped to kindle a love of reading
His speech kindled hope in the hearts of listeners

definitions: stay in a place longer than necessary often because of reluctance to leave
examples: We lingered at the cafe after finishing our meal
The sweet scent of roses lingered in the air

definitions: follow a winding course moving slowly without urgent destination or purpose
examples: The river meanders through the valley creating beautiful curves
We meandered through the old town exploring different shops

definitions: settle oneself comfortably and snugly in a soft or protected place
examples: The kitten nestled in the warm blanket
The cottage nestles among the trees by the lake

definitions: destroy something completely so that nothing remains or can be seen
examples: The tsunami threatened to obliterate the coastal village
Time had obliterated all traces of the ancient road

definitions: spread through and be present in every part of something
examples: The smell of fresh bread pervaded the entire house
A sense of excitement pervaded the crowd before the concert

definitions: satisfy thirst by drinking liquid especially when very thirsty
put out a fire by pouring water or removing oxygen
examples: Nothing quenches thirst better than cold water
The athletes quenched their thirst after the marathon
Firefighters worked quickly to quench the forest fire
Use baking soda to quench a grease fire safely

definitions: voluntarily stop having or owning something giving up control or possession
examples: The king was forced to relinquish his throne
She refused to relinquish her hold on the rope

definitions: examine or inspect something very carefully and thoroughly paying attention to details
examples: The detective scrutinized every piece of evidence
Voters should scrutinize the candidates' voting records

definitions: travel across or through an area especially one that is difficult
examples: It took three days to traverse the mountain range
The bridge allows people to traverse the deep canyon

definitions: damage or weaken something gradually especially someone's power authority or confidence
examples: Constant criticism can undermine a child's self esteem
The scandal threatened to undermine public trust in government

definitions: prove that someone or something is right justified or reasonable after doubt
examples: The test results vindicated her original diagnosis
He felt vindicated when his predictions came true

definitions: take or move someone or something quickly and suddenly
beat eggs cream or other ingredients quickly with a fork or whisk
examples: The waiter whisked away our empty plates immediately
Security whisked the celebrity through the crowd
Whisk the eggs until they become light and fluffy
She whisked the cream to make it thick

definitions: have an intense feeling of longing for something typically unattainable
examples: She yearned to travel the world after graduation
The immigrants yearned for news from their homeland

definitions: move forward by making sharp turns first to one side then the other
examples: The skier zigzagged down the steep mountain slope
Lightning zigzagged across the dark stormy sky

definitions: formally declare someone free from guilt blame or responsibility for something
examples: The court absolved him of all criminal charges
She cannot absolve herself from blame in this matter

definitions: surround a place with armed forces to capture it or force surrender
overwhelm someone with large numbers of requests or complaints
examples: The army besieged the castle for three months
Enemy forces besieged the city cutting off supplies
Reporters besieged the celebrity outside the courthouse
The company was besieged with complaints about the product

definitions: persuade someone to do something by using force threats or pressure
examples: They tried to coerce him into signing the contract
No one should coerce you into making that decision

definitions: reach inside something to search or dig deeply for information or understanding
examples: Historians delve into archives to uncover forgotten stories
The investigation will delve into the company's financial records

definitions: come out from a source and spread outward like light smell or sound
examples: A strange smell emanated from the old basement
Confidence seemed to emanate from the experienced speaker

definitions: understand something complicated or mysterious after much thought especially emotions or reasons
examples: I cannot fathom why she made that decision
It's hard to fathom the depth of their grief

definitions: shock or excite someone into taking action or making effort
examples: The coach's speech galvanized the team before the game
The crisis galvanized the community to work together

definitions: announce or signal that something is about to happen or arrive
examples: The first flowers herald the arrival of spring
Dark clouds herald an approaching storm

definitions: delay or prevent someone or something by creating obstacles to progress
examples: Construction work will impede traffic flow this week
Don't let doubt impede your path to success

definitions: push or shake with a sudden rough movement causing shock
give someone an unpleasant surprise or shock affecting emotions
examples: The bus jolted to a stop throwing passengers forward
The earthquake jolted the building violently
The bad news jolted her out of her daydream
His harsh words jolted me into reality

definitions: work dough or clay by pressing folding and stretching with hands
examples: Knead the bread dough for ten minutes until smooth
The baker kneaded the dough with practiced movements

definitions: criticize someone or something very harshly often publicly and angrily
examples: Critics lambasted the director's latest film
The coach lambasted the team for their poor performance

definitions: make someone less angry or upset by being kind or gentle
examples: She tried to mollify her angry customer with a refund
His apology did little to mollify her hurt feelings

definitions: move or swing back and forth at regular speed between two positions
examples: The pendulum oscillates with a steady rhythm
Her moods oscillate between joy and despair

definitions: fall or drop straight down at high speed losing height or value rapidly
examples: The damaged plane began to plummet toward the ground
Stock prices plummeted after the company announced losses
